title: Wearables may be hot, but they’ve got a ways to go
text:
Wearables may be hot, but they’ve got a ways to go 12:00 a.m. Wednesday, Sept. 30, 2015 | Filed in: Technology Though the number of wearable gadgets shipped is increasing rapidly, they still have issues. “Wearables” is a broad term that includes smartwatches, fitness trackers and clothing with sensors. Experts in wearables believe devices need to be more aesthetic, have better interfaces and work unobtrusively. 
“Wearables” over the last year or two has become one of those terms in technology that’s such a catch-all it sometimes feels like it doesn’t mean much of anything. 
The simplest definition is technology that you wear on your body. That could mean a Fitbit activity tracker a jogger is wearing as they whoosh past you on the Boardwalk Trail at Lady Bird Lake. If you’ve seen a commercial for the Apple Watch, you’ve seen a “wearable.” But it’s also coming to include everything from Bluetooth-enabled jewelry to hearing aids to clothing with sensors built into the fabric (get ready for sweat-detecting bike shorts!), shoes with pedometers built-in or even eyewear like the too-soon-for-the-masses product Google Glass.
